results.title: Canada calling
results.creator_credit: David A. Smith, James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An outline of Canadian radio activity. Commentator John Fisher briefly reviews the history of radio in this country and of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation’s present three-network set-up. The variety of radio fare for Canadians is indicated by snatches of favorite programs; Trio Lyrique; Mart Kenney; the Toronto Symphony; the Happy Gang; forums; religious programs; drama; and old-time music. The variety of people involved in the business of broadcasting is described, and concluding sequences deal with the CBC International Service.

results.title: Canada on stage
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Tim Wilson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Front-seat view of the annual Dominion Drama Festival in Vancouver’s new Queen Elizabeth Theater. Biggest affair of its kind in the world, the Dominion Drama Festival each year brings together the best of Canadian amateur theatrical talent. “Canada on Stage” shows you scenes from prize-winning performances during the week-long festival as Vancouver plays host to groups from all parts of Canada. Caught by the camera is the taut atmosphere after the final curtain as awards are announced by festival adjudicator Phillip Hope Wallace, British drama critic.

results.title: Canada: fibres, yarns and fabrics
results.creator_credit: Gordon Sparling, Julian Biggs, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Shot at Bruck Mills Limited and Dominion Textiles Limited in Montreal, this film shows the rigid tests and quality controls that go into the manufacture of fine Canadian fabrics.

results.title: Canada's National Library
results.creator_credit: John Ralph, Dennis Sawyer, Barrie Howells and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film offers a cinematic tour of Canada’s National Library. It shows that this huge structure in the centre of Ottawa is more than a repository for books. The history of Canada is housed here, preserved in old letters, newspapers, books, music scores and manuscripts. This film provides an interesting overview of the services offered by the library, highlighting the fully automated reference service, which can respond in minutes to the steady flow of inquiries the Library receives from the public. Voice and narration is provided by Bronwyn Drainie.

results.title: Can You Hear Me?
results.creator_credit: John Fitzgerald, New South Wales. Coal Board and Impact Films
results.brief_description: How to protect our amazingly sensitive hearing from the hazard of noise at the workplace. Animation and live action reveal detail of the inner ear where excessive noise can cause permanent deafness. A guideline allows workers to assess dangerous noise levels where ear protection must be worn. Shows adverse social consequences of noise deafness, with straight answers from a doctor.

results.title: Canada's reindeer
results.creator_credit: Inuk Films and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In 1935 a herd of 2,700 reindeer completed a five-year journey from Alaska to north of the Arctic circle. They were imported and re-settled by the Canadian Government in an effort to improve the economic conditions of the Inuit. This film is the story of the trek, the raising of reindeer for saleable meat, its effects upon the people and the transformation of herding from a primitive art to one using modern technology. The film shows how an ecologically sound, make-work project that started as a gamble ended up a success, generating jobs and money for the local people.

results.title: Can we please have that the right way round? (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Features John Cleese and James Cossins preparing a slide presentation and looking back at a series of past disasters. It contains the basic rules of slide presentation and operation in a form designed to stop anyone who sees it from ever making the classic mistakes again. Writer: Dennis Nordern.

results.title: Campbell's Kingdom
results.creator_credit: Ralph Thomas, Betty E. Box and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: After being told that he only has six months to live, Englishman Bruce Campbell (Dirk Bogarde) dedicates his last days to vindicating his late grandfather’s name. His grandfather long held the belief that his land in the Canadian Rocky Mountains, or as he referred to it, ‘kingdom’, contained precious oil reserves; he was alone in his convictions. Bruce, who is now left with the land is determined to strike oil and comes up against fierce resistance from the leader of a construction gang, Owen Morgan (Stanley Baker). With nothing to lose and a suspicion that they are trying to prevent him from discovering the truth, Bruce has a fatalistic determination to get to the bottom of things. Based on the novel by Hammond Innes. Cast includes Dirk Bogarde, Stanley Baker, Michael Craig and James Robertson Justice.

results.title: Camille
results.creator_credit: George Cukor, Turner Entertainment and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Her beauty is the stuff of Hollywood legends, her voice pure magic. Screen legend, Greta Garbo is captured at the very summit of her career. In one of the most romantic tales ever put on film, Garbo is breathtaking as the doomed courtesan whose passion for romance is equalled only by her passion for life. From her first appearance in the luxurious carriage that sweeps her off to the opera, to her last gasp in the arms of her broken hearted lover, Garbo’s performance makes an indelible impression. As Armand Duval, her ardent suitor, Robert Taylor cuts a striking figure that makes the futility of his love all the more poignant. The supporting roles are similarly cast with uncanny accuracy. Lionel Barrymore is commanding as Armand’s well-meaning father; Henry Daniell chills one’s blood with his sadistic portrayal of the Baron de Varville.

results.title: Can-can
results.creator_credit: Walter Lang, Jack Cummings and Suffolk-Cummings Productions
results.brief_description: It’s 1896 and the “naughty” Can-Can has been banned in Paris. That doesn’t stop a vivacious cafe owner, (Shirley MacLaine), from performing it anyway, much to the delight of her patrons. She’s been able to ignore the law because her clever lawyer, (Frank Sinatra), has a corrupt judge, (Maurice Chevalier), in his pocket. Their sweet setup abruptly changes when a new judge, (Louis Jourdan), decides to put a stop to this shocking behaviour. Little does he know, that the real fun and excitement is just beginning! Features three Cole Porter songs that were not in the original hit show, lavish sets, stunning costumes and plenty of high-stepping dance numbers. Like Paris in the summer, Can-Can sizzles!
